The main issue of concern is either router compromise or frontend compromise via NPM or smt 

In this case you can assume all the frontends will trigger ledger / rabby with malicious txs so you need a reliable way of validating the JSON on SAFE with that txn hash that is being signed 

This is exceptionally fun because almost all Ledger + SAFE txns are blind signed

I looked into this tonight and aparently it's why a lot of people are getting done on SAFE+Ledger

AFAIK the SAFE hash comparison is utterly pointless if there is an injected script that replaces the tx with a malicious tx and same nonce

Similarly, you can't trust any frontend really to present this information, it has to be locally ran using the hash of the JSON in the SAFE - assuming you know enough about the hash to validate that it is indeed correct
